description: From Middle English prevailen, from Old French prevaler, from Latin praevaleō (“be very able or more able, be superior, prevail”), from prae (“before”) + valeō (“be able or powerful”). Displaced native Old English rīcsian.

verbs.description: prevail (third-person singular simple present prevails, present participle prevailing, simple past and past participle prevailed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be superior in strength, dominance, influence, or frequency; to have or gain the advantage over others; to have the upper hand; to outnumber others.
examples: Red colour prevails in the Canadian flag.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be current, widespread, or predominant; to have currency or prevalence.
examples: In his day and age, such practices prevailed all over Europe.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To succeed in persuading or inducing.
examples: I prevailed on him to wait.
